loans.name: Hope To God Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the “Hope To God” group from Lunsar, a town in northern Sierra Leone. They are small business people who will be able to add more goods to their businesses, attract more customers, increase sales and profit, and consequently improve their living conditions. 

The leader of this group of entrepreneurs is Agnes. Agnes is 42; she was born in northern Sierra Leone. She is married, and has three children, one of whom is attending primary school. 

Agnes sells palm-oil (the most popular cooking oil), fish, bananas, fried cakes, etc... With her share of this loan, she is going to buy fish, bananas, etc... to add to her business. She will also buy flour, oil, etc. in order to fry a larger quantity of cakes for sale. 

(Also included on the right of the photo is loan officer Sarah, posing with the borrowers).

loans.use: to buy fish, bananas, etc. to add to her business. She will also buy flour, oil, etc. in order to fry a larger quantity of cakes for sale.

loans.name: Jeniffer

texts.en:
Jeniffer is 54 years old,  married, and supporting a family of six.  Her spouse supports her in meeting some of their financial needs. 

Jeniffer runs a small scale farming business; she has been in this business for ten years with an average income of KES. 30,000 a month. 

Jeniffer has borrowed a second loan of KES. 100,000, to purchase farm inputs, as well as tilling and other operations in preparation for the next planting season. 

With the anticipated profits, she intends to expand her business by starting a dairy farming business to diversify her source of income. She will also pay school fees for her children. 

Her future plan is to buy a farm to enable her to expand her farming business.

loans.use: To purchase farm inputs and prepare the land for the upcoming planting season.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more cattle, and manure for fertilizing his banana crop.

loans.name: Work Hard Group

texts.en:
Haja leads this group of five entrepreneurs. She was born in the village of Tandata, in northern Sierra Leone, 30 years ago and is married to a businessman and the mother of three children, two of whom attend primary schools. For 10  years now, she has earned a living by selling various kinds of food – palm-oil (the most popular cooking oil), onions, pepper, tomatoes, margi (which is used to give sauce as sweet taste), fish and other items. With the help of this loan, Haja and her group members will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and improve their living conditions. Haja will use her share of the loan (SLL 700,000) to buy food items in bulk to expand her current inventory.  

(Also included on the right of the photo is loan officer Rosaline posing with the clients).

loans.use: to buy various food items to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Larisa

texts.en:
Larisa is a 52-year-old and lives in Ozurgeti with her son and daughter-in-law. 

Several times, Larisa has requested loans from local financial institutions for her trading business start-up, but without any success. Her loan request was rejected each time because of low income and the lack of experience in her new business. Income and experience are usually demanded by local credit providers. 

The only source of income for the family is the small monthly income earned by Larisa, who is involved in a small-scale trading business. She buys clothing, dishes, cosmetics and different kinds of household items in Turkey and resells these items to nearby villages. 

Larisa requested a loan from Credo to expand her business. Her loan request was approved in the framework of a new joint initiative between Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisages the provision of business start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions to the country's rural poor. The rural poor do not have access to credit products, being regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of low income. 

Larisa will purchase more clothing and household items in Turkey at wholesale prices and resell the items for a profit. It will be hard work for Larisa, but according to estimations, her business will be profitable and will increase the income of the family. The increased profit will be reinvested in clothing trading to increase her stock and sales volume. 

The family members will be able to improve their living conditions. Larisa awaits your support.

loans.use: to purchase clothing and household items for resale.

loans.name: Unity Group

texts.en:
Meet the members of the Unity Group from Lunsar, a town in northern Sierra Leone. They are all local entrepreneurs who have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva, to apply for a loan of SLL 500,000 for each person. With the help of this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales, and consequently improve their living conditions. 

Melrose is the leader of this group. Melrose is married, and the couple has two children, who are attending primary and secondary schools. Melrose sells palm oil (the country's most popular cooking oil), beans and charcoal. She has been doing business for seven years. With the help of this loan, Melrose is going to buy the above-mentioned items in large quantity, to add to her current stock. 

(Included at the right side of the photo is loan officer Sarah, posing with the borrowers.)

loans.use: to buy palm oil, beans and charcoal in large quantity, to add to her current stock

loans.name: Kagadi Subcounty Youth Group

texts.en:
Bosco is a married man, aged 25 years old, with one child. He looks after his parents. He rears goats and also grows sugarcane as a major source of income to look after his family.

Bosco wants a loan to buy more goats to rear as well as to improve on his sugarcane plantation so that he can realize good returns from the business and be in a position to look after the family. His dream is to expand on the goat rearing business and also buy a machine for brewing locally processed gin out of his sugarcane.

However, Bosco's major challenge is limited capital together with the unpredictable weather which is affecting his agricultural projects. He is grateful to the group for making him part of the group as this has become a gateway for opportunities.

loans.use: To buy goats to rear

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to pay tuition fees for his children.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en: Josephine is widowed with six children and only three of her children go to school. She has a business of selling fruits and vegetables. She has been in this fruit business for 10 years. She has applied for a loan of 300,000 Uganda Shillings from MCDT-SACCO to buy more boxes of passionfruit, mangoes, onions, tomatoes, pumpkins, oranges, and tangerines. She doesn’t have any other income-generating activity and works seven days out of every week.  Her major business challenges include seasonality and perishabilty. She aspires to become a wholesaler and also to educate her children up to university. She resides in her own house and the family doesn’t have access to electricity or piped water. Her monthly expenses include school and rent

loans.use: To buy more boxes of passionfruit, mangoes, onions, tomatoes, and pumpkins

loans.name: Silvia

texts.es: Silvia con su anterior credikiva compró un congelador, nuevo y está produciendo mucho mas hielo. También su crédito anterior lo benefició mucho en su negocio de venta de minutos a celulares y papelería además de accesorios femeninos. Con su venta de hielo en mayor cantidad, está consolidándose, sus hijos tienen una actitud positiva con muchas ganas de salir adelante también con trabajos independientes. Su mensaje a los financiadores de Kiva es el siguiente: “Con responsabilidad, dedicación e imaginación, se pueden sacar los negocios adelante. “ En la actualidad está aplicando a un nuevo credikiva con el cual comprará productos comestibles, mercancía de miscelánea, papelería, útiles escolares, accesorios femeninos etc, con esta inversión planea aumentar sus utilidades y esto es justamente la razón de éxito de su credikiva bien invertido.
texts.en: Silvia used her previous Kiva loan to buy a new freezer and she is making much more ice.  The money also helped her with her cell phone card, paper goods, and feminine accessories business.  She is consolidating her business by selling ice in bulk.  Her children have a positive attitude and a great desire to get ahead with their own work.  Her message to the Kiva lenders is, “With responsibility, dedication, and imagination, one can get ahead in one’s business.”  She is using her Kiva loan to buy edible items, miscellaneous merchandise, paper goods, school utensils, ladies’ accessories, etc.  She plans to increase her utility through this investment and this successful use for her Kiva loan.

loans.use: to stock her business.

loans.name: Trinidad

texts.es:
Doña Trinidad, tiene 51 años de edad, es madre soltera, tiene tres hijos quienes ya son independientes, vive en una aldea que pertenece al municipio de Taulabe, Comayagua.
hace 10 años que doña trinidad decidió establecer su propio negocio en un puesto del mercado local, donde vende toda clase de verduras, como repollo, tomate, chile, pepinos, habichuelas, cebolla, yuca, limones, papas, banano verde etc. Ella ha mantenido varios prestamos con ODEF, los que le han ayudado a fortalecer su negocio, actualmente lleva doce ciclos con este préstamo que solicita que es por 15,000 Lempiras, el cual lo invertirá en la compra de mas producto como repollo, tomate, cebolla, chile, yuca, papas, bananos, habichuelas, etc. esta inversión le ayudara a tener mayor inventario y a incrementar las ventas. Su meta es mejorar su negocio para tener mejor vida y siempre ahorrar para el futuro.
texts.en:
Trinidad, 51, is a single mother; she has three children who are all now independent.  She lives in a village belonging to the municipality of Taulabe, Comayagua.

Ten years ago Trinidad decided to start her own business in a stand in a local market selling all kinds of vegetables like cabbage, tomatoes, chilies, cucumbers, beans, onions, manioc, lemons, potatoes, green plantain, etc.  She’s stayed in business thanks to several ODEF loans that have helped her strengthen the business.  To date, she’s been in 12 loan cycles counting this one which is for 15,000 Lempiras she’ll use to buy more products like cabbage, tomatoes, onion, chilies, manioc, potatoes, plantain, beans, etc.  This investment will help her have a larger inventory and to increase sales.  Her goal is to improve her business to have a better life and always save up for the future.

loans.use: to buy vegetables.

loans.name: Gocha

texts.en:
Gocha is 47 years old. He is married, and he lives with his wife and daughter. His daughter goes to the local kindergarten. Gocha is a shoemaker and makes shoes, which he sells from his house. His wife runs a small-scale trading business, selling clothing among their neighbors.

Gocha has requested credit to expand his business. His loan request was approved, in the framework of a new joint initiative between Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisages providing business start-ups and restart-ups with credit on soft conditions, for the country's rural poor people, who do not have access to regular credit products, being regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of their low income.

With the received credit, Gocha will start up a small workshop, and he will buy soles and leather materials with which to make shoes. He will produce more shoes and sell his products for a good price. The new business initiative will increase the monthly income for the family. Their living conditions will improve, and in the future, they will have enough income to access regular credit products available on the country’s capital market, in the event of need.

loans.use: to start up a small workshop and buy materials that will enable him to make more shoes

loans.name: Hanan

texts.en:
Hanan is a 38-year-old married woman and the mother of four children. She has been providing educational services since seven years ago. Hanan helps her husband a lot in covering their children’s expenses through teaching students at her house.

Hanan is applying for a loan from Kiva partner Al Majmoua in order to buy a car that will help her expand her working zone through going to nearby villages on weekends and providing special educational services.

Hanan is well known for her special reputation and hard work. This is her second cycle as an Al Majmoua borrower. She has a good standing in paying-back history.

Hanan hopes that one day she will be capable of opening an educational center.

loans.use: to buy a car to expand her working zone.

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en:
Ibrahim is married, with three children; one of them is in school. He sells second-hand clothes in the outskirt markets of Kagadi town, a business he started ten years ago as a major source of income to look after his family.

He wants a loan of 1,000,000 UGX (one million shillings) to buy more second-hand shoes for selling to meet the increasing demand for the goods. It is back-to-school season, so parents will be buying shoes for their children. His major challenge is the limited capital in the business, and the poor transportation network to the markets.

Ibrahim hopes to expand his business and get good income from it to help him educate his children, and also construct a permanent residential house for the family. 

He asks lenders to give him a hand financially, and see his dream come true.

In the photo is Ibrahim(left) with the Ugafode credit officer who had gone to do a site visit at his home.

loans.use: To buy second-hand shoes for selling.

loans.name: Frank

texts.en:
Frank is a 28 year-old-man dealing in the coffee trade as his primary source of income. The photo shows Frank in his coffee store.

He applied for a loan of 1,000,000 UGX to purchase more coffee for sale. He has had this business for three years, and has gained commendable experience in the business.  Frank purchases the coffee from farmers, dries it, processes it, and sells it at a profit. He applied for the loan so he can increase his stock. He plans to store the coffee until prices go up and sell it at a better price, above the market price.

Frank plans to buy a piece of land and plant more coffee on it. He also intends to diversify his business into goat’s trade, so as to increase his house hold income.

loans.use: Purchase more coffee beans to process and resell.

loans.name: Samuel R.'s Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are teachers from one of the primary schools in Lunsar, a town in northern Sierra Leone. This group of teachers has come to SMT, a partner of Kiva.org based in Makeni, northern Sierra Leone to request a loan of 17,600,000 Leones for the entire group. With the help of this loan, these teachers will be able to buy or invest in things that their mere salaries can not let them buy or invest in. At the end of each month, they will repay the loan using their monthly salaries. It is their school’s bursar who is directly responsible for doing the repayments on their behalf.

Samuel is the featured leader of this group. Samuel is 53 years old. A native of Yoni Bana chiefdom in northern Sierra Leone, he is married with four children – one in primary school and two in secondary school. Samuel is a school teacher and has served in the teaching profession for 34 years now. He has requested this loan to buy house building materials in order to renovate his house.

loans.use: to buy house building materials in order to renovate his house

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To pay her dependent's school fees

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To  construct a bigger poultry house .

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy items for the retail shop

loans.name: Christina

texts.en:
Christina lives in the Nanyuki area of Central province, Kenya. She is a married mother of four children. She owns a tea tree farming business, a business which she has been operating for one year now. She also has been doing farming, mainly planting maize, beans and potatoes. The oil from the tea tree is used to manufacture cosmetics.

She learnt about Milango through a friend who invited her to the group; she joined the group with an aim of accessing credit to better her business operations. The main challenge she faces is lack of water.

Christina is applying for a loan of 10,734 Kenya shillings to buy tea tree seedlings for the business. Her extra income from the loan will be added to the savings to expand the agricultural business. Her future plan in five years time is to expand the acreage under tea trees and also open a grocery stall.

loans.use: To buy tea tree seedlings for the business.

loans.name: Dora

texts.es: Dora con su credikiva compró materias primas e insumos y los utilizó para preparar mucha mas comida rápida. Con su financiamiento no tuvo la necesidad de prestar dinero a personas informales con intereses muy onerosos y eso fue muy bueno, porque ganó mucho mas a l comercializar. En la actualidad emprendió un nuevo negocio en su casa, mediante el cual vende refrescos y abre sus puertas en la mañana y en la tarde; Dora está muy feliz y agradecida con su credikiva y dice que con sus financiadores ha logrado el nuevo negocio que le representa otra fuente de ingresos. Por eso está acudiendo a un nuevo credikiva, con el cual planea crecer mucho mas y en esta vez comprará refrescos para fortalecer su nueva actividad y generar otras utilidades.
texts.en:
With her last loan, Dora bought supplies and staple goods which she used to prepare fast food to sell. Thanks to the financing, she didn’t need to borrow money from unreliable people who charge high interest rates, which was good because she made more profits from her sales. She has just started a new business from home selling soft drinks. She opens in the morning and afternoon. 

Dora is very happy and grateful for her Kiva loan and says that due to the financial support received she has been able to start a new business which is another source of income for her. She is requesting a new loan to be able to grow more, this time buying soft drinks to strengthen her new business and generate more profits.

loans.use: to buy soft drinks to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy wood to burn bricks

loans.name: Mursi

texts.en:
Mursi is a 25-year-old married man from Tulkarem. He lives in a simple house with his wife and one son. Mursi is a worker with a low wage, his salary barely covers the family's needs. Mursi wants to improve the family's housing conditions. Now he works to fix the outside stairs for the family's house.

Mursi took a $3,000 Youth loan from FATEN. This loan will help Mursi to improve the standards of living for his family, so they can enjoy living in their house.

Mursi photographed in front of his house.

loans.use: To pay the expenses for fixing the home stairs

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice's Group is comprised of  hard-working women. Alice is 20 years old and lives in the town of Kyotera, in the Masaka region of Uganda. For the past two years, Alice has been working hard to manage the rearing of cattle, whose milk she sells. 

To help expand her business, Alice has requested a loan of UGX 600,000 (Ugandan Shillings) from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more cattle for milk and buckets to collect the milk in and will help Alice to generate greater profits and take care of her family members by providing all the basic needs. Alice hopes that, in the future, she will be able to own many cows that will produce much milk. 

Alice is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more cattle for milk and buckets to collect the milk in.

loans.name: Suren

texts.en:
Livingwater Pool Service, located in Fresno, CA, is a sole proprietorship that performs general pool cleaning and repair services.  It was established in 2011 after Suren lost his jobs as a smog technician with a local shop, and driver for a medical transport company.  Suren realized that there was an opportunity in pool service due to Fresno’s location in the heart of the Golden State where the winters are short and mild, and outdoor swimming temperatures are prevalent nine months out of the year.
 
Suren is seeking $2,000 for working capital to purchase parts and supplies.  He gets a lot of repair jobs in winter and spring and the funds will help him with larger jobs that require him to buy parts up front.

Suren is an entrepreneur at heart.  After losing both jobs in the recession, he started the pool cleaning and repair service business using his savings to acquire a pickup truck and tools.  Suren works hard to build his customer base and is proud that so many of his customers are referring their friends and family members to him.  He is unable to get a business loan from local banks.

Suren and his wife came to America as refugees from Armenia in 2005.  They have three children ages 9, 8 and 6.

loans.use: to purchase inventory for pool repair.

loans.name: Toji

texts.ru:
Тоджи  женщина в возрасте 50 лет. Она замужем, имеет пятерых детей и 10 внуков.  Тоджи  вместе со своим мужем всю свою жизнь занимается откормом скота так как они оба не имеют образования.  Откармливая скот они вырастили пятерых детей.  Это их единственный доход в семье. Дети пока не где не работают только помогают своим родителям по откорму скота.  Они с мужем очень стараются помогать своим детям в надежде что в старости они будут им опорой. Это семья очень дружная и трудолюбивая.
На полученный кредит Тоджи планирует купить скот и увеличить  поголовье скота. Тоджи и его семья очень благодарны организации Кива за то, что благодаря таким организациям как Кива,  люди нуждавшийся в финансовой поддержке могут осуществить свои планы.
texts.en:
Toji is a 50 year old woman.  She is married and has five children and 10 grandchildren.  Toji together with her husband has been raising livestock her whole life because they both do not have an education.  While raising livestock they raised five children.  This is their sole source of income for their family.  The children do not work anywhere right now, they just help their parents raise livestock.  She and her husband try hard to help their children in the hope that they will be their support in old age.  This family is very close and hardworking.   

Toji plans to use the loan to buy livestock and increase her livestock count.  Toji and her family are very grateful to Kiva, because thanks to organizations like Kiva people who need financial support can bring their plans to fruition.

loans.use: to buy cattle

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en: Joseph is a resident of Katembe in Isingiro District. He is married with four children and also has four dependents whom he took over from his brother who died of AIDS. He did not go to school but has spent all his life as a cattle keeper, a business that has enabled him to take care of his family. He is requesting a loan of 2,500,000 Uganda shillings to dig up stumps and remove thorny bushes so that the land can be used for grazing. He also  plans to fence his farm.

loans.use: To  prepare land for grazing and to buy poles and fencing materials

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy materials to complete his residential house

loans.name: Madina

texts.en:
Madina is a single mother of three children, and two of her children go to school. She doesn't take care of any additional family members. She has a tailoring business where she generates additional income, and she has been in this business for three years.  She sells to all types of people on retail. 

Madina has applied for a loan of Ugandan shillings from MCDT SACCO to buy more rolls of clothing material and thread. She generates additional income through poultry keeping. She works from a shop that she rents six days a week.  Her major business challenges include seasonality, defaulters and high rental charges.  She aspires to become one of the top fashion designers in Uganda and also to build her own house.  She resides in a rented house, and the family has no access to electricity or piped water.  Her monthly expenses include school fees and rent.

loans.use: to buy more rolls of clothing material and thread.

loans.name: Kulumbu

texts.ru: Кулумбу 52 года, замужем, имеет 2 сыновей. Дети Кулумбу взрослые закончили школу, оба сына помогают ао хозяйству. Кулумбу имеет многолетний опыт в животноводстве. Кулумбу содержит небольшое хозяйство в  1 корову, 1 лошадь, 1 теленка,26 овец и 31 козу. Ежедневно Кулумбу сдает молоко производителям молочной продукции и но все же в основном занимается раведением и продажей скота, что приносит около 17,000 сом (KGS) в месяц. В целях дальнейшего расширения своего бизнеса, Кулумбу обратилась в компанию «Бай - Тушум и Партнеры» за кредитом в сумме 40,000 сом (KGS) на покупку дойных коров. Доходы от кредита Кулубу планирует вложить в дальнейшее расширение хозяйства.
texts.en: Kulumbu is 52 years old and has 2 sons.  Kulumbu's children are adults and finished school, both sons help her with her holdings.  Kulumbu has many years of experience in raising livestock.  Kulumbu has a small farm with 1 cow, 1 horse, 1 calf, 26 sheep and 31 goats.  Everyday Kulumbu sells milk to dairy product manufacturers and mostly raises and sells livestock, which brings her around 17,000 som (KGS) per month.  In order to further grow her business, Kulumbu turned to "Bai-Tushum & Partners" for a loan of 40,000 som (KGS) to purchase milk cows.  Kulumbu plans to use the profits from the loan to further expand her holdings.

loans.use: to purchase milk cows

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Toutes mariées, les femmes  du groupe  Benkadi  qui ont  une moyenne d’âge de 35 ans et 4 enfants vivent majoritairement dans des familles traditionnelles dans le quartier Massablacoura de la ville de Bougouni. 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, d’amitié et de commerce. Pour renforcer leur capacité financière afin de mieux faire leur commerce, elles ont adhéré  à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle elles sont à leur sixième  prêt. Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce de céréales et de condiments. 
Rokia, qui a le papier en main fait l’achat vente de céréales (mil, maïs, arachide, sorgho, etc). 
Elle compte acheter avec son  prêt, 500 kilos d’arachide décortiqué auprès des forains de  à Bougouni. Elle effectue ses ventes au marché  et à domicile, en détail au comptant et à crédit  à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 50.000FCFA qui sera  investi dans les activités,  utilisé pour les frais de santé et rembourser le prêt.
texts.en:
The members of the Benkadi group are all married women averaging 35 years of age, with four children. They lvie mainly in traditional families in the Massablacoura district of the town of Bougouni.

They know each other as neighbors and friends as well as through their work. In order to bolster the financing capacity and improve their business, they have joined the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution and are now on their 6th group. The group members sell cereals and condiments.
Rokia, the one holding documents in her hand, sells cereals (millet, corn, peanuts, sorghum, etc). She plans to use her loan to buy 500 kg [1102 lbs] of shelled peanuts at the market in Bougoini. She sells at the market and out of her home, retail, for cash and on credit, to a customer base composed of both men and women.
She plans to achieve an average monthly income of 50,000 West African francs, which will be used to invest in her business, cover healthcare expenses and repaid her loan.

loans.use: to buy peanuts.

loans.name: Sulaiman

texts.en:
Sulaiman is one of UGAFODE Microfinance Limited – Rukungiri's customers who joined about seven years ago. He has various businesses, although his main source of income is cattle slaughtering. He is a butcher and he operates in different markets in Bwambara, especially during market days. He joined UGAFODE Microfinance Limited for financial assistance to increase his business sales and income of the household. With his loan, he will buy cows and goats for slaughter.

He has been able to improve his businesses and has managed to meet the responsibilities of the home. In this regard, all activities he does are of high quality and come with experience, in terms of slaughtering animals and marketing his cows and goats to the different consumers.

Sulaiman has managed to increase the capacity of his butchery business as well as the rice plantations at his home in rural Rukungiri. He has also put all eight of his children in school since he now has the capacity of paying school fees for them, plus taking care of the other family needs for the children and his wife.

He thanks UGAFODE Microfinance Limited for all the services, but says that the institution should reduce on the interest rate to enable him to increase his profits.

loans.use: He will buy cows and goats for slaughter.

loans.name: Yulduzoi

texts.ru:
Юлдузой пришла в МДО Арванд, чтобы получить кредит для развития своего бизнеса. Она не замужем и живет с отцом.   Она содержит скот дома. Раньше она с отцом откармливала скот но сейчас  ее отец состарился и не может этим делом заниматься, поэтому Юлдузой приходиться откармливать одной для содержания семьи. Она сама покупает и продает скот.  Ей очень нравиться этот бизнес так как дает хороший доход.  Это  единственный доход в семье, она не училась так как были финансовые трудности в семье и вынуждена заниматься только откармливанием скота. Юлдузой очень пунктуальная и ответственная девушка.  
 На полученный кредит Юлдузой планирует купить скот и увеличить поголовье скота.  Она надеется на финансовую поддержку от организации Кива и заранее благодарит.
texts.en: Yulduzoi applied to MDO Arvand for a loan to developing her business. She is single and lives with her father. She raises livestock by her home. In the past, she used to raise livestock together with her father, but now her father has aged and is no longer able to continue this work. Therefore Yulduzoi has  to take care of the livestock on her own, in order to support the household. She buys and sells livestock on her own. She really likes this business as it brings in a good income. This is the sole source of income in the household. Yulduzoi did not pursue her studies as her family had financial difficulties, and she had no choice but to raise livestock. Yulduzoi is a very punctual and responsible young woman. She plans to use this loan to buy livestock and increase the headcount. She  counts on Kiva’s financial support and thanks you in advance.

loans.use: to buy  cattle.

loans.name: Moniuma

texts.en:
Moniuma lives in Sinkor, one of the areas where living conditions are almost the same as those for the people who live in the center of Monrovia. She is 36 years old, married and has three children between ages of four and 17 who are in school and live at home. She was able to attend school. 

For 15 years now, she has been involved in local soap-making. Sometimes her customers take credit and don't pay. She learned this trade from her school. She likes her business because it makes her self-sufficient. She is requesting a loan to purchase caustic soda, wood, oil and plastic for her business. Her plan is to build her house and take care of her children.

loans.use: to purchase caustic soda, wood, oil and plastic for her business.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: helps a member to stop depending on diesel lamps for lighting and allows each of them to buy a reliable solar home system for quality lighting and cell-phone charging for their households

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: helps a member to have access to a clean energy source that will effectively replace their current lighting service, used only in situations they consider an emergency and that represent an incredible financial effort.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: helps a member to dramatically increase their living standard, by acquiring a solar system that will provide clean solar energy for their families.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: helps a member to improve their living standards dramatically, because it would allow them to obtain a solar system that will provide clean solar energy for their households.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: helps a member to acquire a clean energy source for their households: a solar energy system.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: helps a member to stop depending on diesel lamps for lighting and allows each of them to buy a reliable solar home system for quality lighting and cell-phone charging for their households

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: helps a member to have a reliable source of lighting in case of emergencies and to decrease their expenses used in the bad quality energy services they have.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: helps a member to stop depending on diesel lamps, candles and ocote for lighting and allows each of them to buy a reliable solar home system for quality lighting and cell-phone charging for their households

loans.name: Reuben

texts.en:
Reuben lives in Nanyuki area of Central province, Kenya. He is married and has two children. He owns a tea tree farm, a business he has been operating for one year now. Besides this, he has been a horticultural farmer, planting potatoes, maize, beans and cattle rearing for seven years. The oil from the tea tree plant is used to manufacture cosmetics.

He learned about Milango through a friend who invited him to join the group and he joined with an aim of accessing credit to improve on his business operations. His main challenges are lack of funds and water.

Reuben is applying for a loan of 10,734 Kenya shillings to buy tea tree seedlings. His extra income will be added to his savings to improve the living standards of his family. He aspires to expand the area under tea tree cultivation.

loans.use: To to buy tea tree seedlings.

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en:
Stephen lives in Nanyuki area of Central province, Kenya. He is married and has two children. He owns a tea tree farm, a business he has been operating for one year now. Besides this, he has been a horticultural farmer, planting potatoes, maize, French beans and for fifteen years. The oil from the tea tree plant is used to manufacture cosmetics.

He learned about Milango through a friend who invited him to join the group and he joined with an aim of accessing credit to improve on his business operations. His main challenges are lack of funds and water.

Stephen is applying for a loan of 10,734 Kenya shillings to buy tea tree seedlings. His extra income will be added to his savings to improve the living standards of his family. He aspires to expand the area under tea tree cultivation.

loans.use: To buy tea tree seedlings.

loans.name: Robert

texts.en:
Robert is a 47-year-old married man. He has five children with ages ranging from eight to 21. He describes himself as a business-oriented man. He operates a poultry business where he sells chickens. He has been involved in this business for 13 years. His business is located in a highly populated area and his primary customers are local residents. He describes his biggest business challenge to be insufficient funds for improving the business. 

He will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy chickens to sell. His business goal is to add more chickens to sell within five years. He hopes that in the future, he will run a wholesale business. This is his first loan with SMEP DTM.

loans.use: to buy chickens to sell.

loans.name: Charles

texts.en:
Charles lives in Nanyuki area of Central province, Kenya. He is married and has three children. He owns a tea tree farm, a business he has been operating for one year now. Besides this, he has been a horticultural farmer, planting potatoes, maize, beans and for ten years. The oil from the tea tree plant is used to manufacture cosmetics.

He learned about Milango through a friend who invited him to join the group, and he joined with an aim of accessing credit to improve on his business operations. His main challenges are lack of funds and water.

Charles is applying for a loan of 10,734 Kenya shillings to buy tea tree seedlings. His extra income will be added to his savings to improve the living standards of his family. He aspires to expand the area under tea tree cultivation.

loans.use: To buy tea tree seedlings.

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter lives in Nanyuki area of Central province, Kenya. He is married and has four children. He owns a tea tree farm, a business he has been operating for one year now. Besides this, he has been a horticultural farmer, planting potatoes, maize, beans for the last fifteen years. The oil from his tea-tree plantation is used to manufacture cosmetics.

He learned about Milango through a friend who invited him to join the group and he joined with an aim of accessing credit to improve on his business operations. His main challenges are lack of funds and water.

Peter is applying for a loan of 20,730 Kenya shillings to cultivate the land for horticultural farming. His extra income will be added to his savings to improve the living standards of his family. He aspires to expand the area under tea tree cultivation.

loans.use: To cultivate the land for horticultural farming.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth  lives in Sinkor,  one of the areas where living conditions are almost like the people who live in the center of Monrovia. She is 49 years old and married with five children between ages of 30 to 20  that are in school  but only one lives at home; she is a 9th grade student. 

Since 1999 Elizabeth has been involved in the sale of dried fish. Sometimes her customers buy on credit and don’t pay on time. She learned this way of selling from her friend whom she calls "my motivator',  and she likes her business because it makes her  self-sufficient. She is requesting a loan to purchase dried fish  for her business. Her plan is to build a house.

loans.use: to purchase dried fish  for her business

loans.name: Annet

texts.en:
Annet, aged 37, is a resident of Rwashamaire, Nyabihoko, Kajara, a surbub of Ntungamo.

She is a single mother who has five children and also has a small restaurant in a slightly busy trading centre. She wants a loan of 300,000 UGX to help her pay fees for the children and buy some items for her business.

Her challenges are competition and price fluctuation which increase the price of commodities yet the price of the meals has to remain the same.

loans.use: To pay school fees and buy food.

loans.name: Henrietta

texts.en:
Henrietta lives in Montserrado County, in which lies the capital city of Liberia (Monrovia). Montserrado County is well-known as the commercial center of Liberia. She is 48 years old, married, and has three children between 13 and 32 years old. Only one is in school and lives at home.

For the past four years, Henrietta has been selling used clothes in the local market. She started this business with money from her husband, and she learned this way of selling from mother. She enjoys her business, because of the profit she makes every day. Henrietta is requesting a loan to buy more used clothes for her business. She wants to build a house for her children, in the near future.

loans.use: to buy more used clothes for her business inventory.

loans.name: Babygirl

texts.en:
Babygirl lives in  Montserrado county, Sinkor, one of the areas that is almost like the center of Monrovia. She is 32 years old and lives together  with her boyfriend and two children aged 7 and 10. Her children are attending school as elementary students.

Babygirl has been running a table  for the past four years on which she sells peppers, rice, palm oil, Vita, onions,  and okra in the local market. The profit from her business is used  on food and house rent. She started this business with money from her boyfriend. She spends 9 hours a day on her business, and enjoys the response (buying) of her customers. She takes a taxi to get the goods on her table from the wholesale store. She is requesting a loan to purchase more peppers, rice, palm oil, Vita, onions, and okra for her business. Her plan is to own a house.

loans.use: to purchase more peppers, rice, palm oil, Vita, onions, and okra for her business.

loans.name: Priscilla

texts.en: Priscilla is a married woman. She has four children between the ages of 10 and 25. She describes herself to be a dedicated and humble woman. She operates a tailoring retail store where she sells clothes she makes. She has been involved in this business for 10 years. Her business is located at a very busy area, and her primary customers are the general public. She describes her biggest business challenge to be lack of enough funds for business expansion. She will use the 20,000 KES loan to buy materials for making clothes. Her business goal is to run a new business of a wholesale shop within five years. She hopes that in the future, she will build a permanent house. This is her third loan with SMEP DTM after taking a loan of 20,000 KES, which she managed to repay successfully.

loans.use: to buy materials for making clothes

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase merchandise such as grapefruits, pineapples, bananas, oranges, and watermelons at wholesale prices.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy household items for his retail store's inventory.

loans.name: Sumini

texts.en:
Sumini  is widowed with five children and all her children do go to school. She also takes care of additional family members (3 young sisters). She has a business of market vending and has been in this business for three years.  She has applied for a loan of 300,000 Uganda shillings from MCDT-SACCO to buy more boxes of tomatoes, onions, cabbages and mangoes. She generates additional income through washing people's clothes. She moves door to door selling fruit and vegetables and sells retail only.  

Sumini's major business challenges include transport, seasonality and paying water bills. She is aspiring of becoming a wholesaler and getting permanent business premises. She resides in a rented house and the family house has no access to electricity or piped water. Her monthly expenses include rent and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more tomatoes, onions, cabbages and mangoes

loans.name: Patience

texts.en: Patience lives in Montserrado County, the capital city of Liberia; it is well known as the commercial city  of Liberia. She is 24 years old and married with two children aged 3 and 5 years old, that are in school and live at home. For the past six years she has been selling slippers in the community market. She started this business with help from her mother and learned this way of selling from her. She likes her business because it gives her a lot of profit. She is requesting a loan to buy more slippers  for her business. She wants to get more money to educate her children.

loans.use: to buy more slippers  for her business

loans.name: Samuew

texts.en:
Samuew is a 40-year-old, married man. He has five children, with ages ranging from two years to 14 years. He describes himself to be a hard-working and innovative man. 

He operates a carpentry workshop where he sells furniture. He has been involved in this business for 12 years. His business is located in a less-competitive area and his primary customers are local dwellers. He describes his biggest business challenge to be the high price of timber. 

Samuew will use the KES 40,000 loan to buy timber. His business goal is to expand his business within five years. He hopes that, in the future, he will build a permanent house for his family. This is his second loan with SMEP Deposit Taking Microfinance Limited (SMEP DTM), after taking a loan of KES 20,000 which he managed to successfully repay.

loans.use: to buy timber to make more furniture to sell.

loans.name: Annie

texts.en:
Annie lives in Montserrado County, in which lies the capital city of Liberia, Monrovia. It is well-known as the commercial center of Liberia. She is 48 years old, married, and has six children between 17 and 29 years old. Five of her children are in school and live at home.

For the past four years, Annie has been selling charcoal in her community. She started this business with help from her mother and learned this way of selling from her. She likes her business, because it gives her more profit. She is requesting a loan to buy more charcoal for her business. Her future goals are to get  money to educate all her children and to own a house.

loans.use: to buy more charcoal to resell to customers.

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en:
Daniel  is a married man. He has 5 children. He describes himself to be jovial, dedicated to his work and ambitious. He operates a 'posho' mill business where he mills maize into flour. He has been involved in this business for five years. His business is located at a potential business area and his primary customers are local dwellers. 

Daniel describes his biggest business challenge to be lack of enough space for business operation. He will use the Kes 60,000 loan to buy a grinding maize machine (a mill). His business goal is to run another 'posho' mill retail store  within five years. This is his fourth loan with SMEP DTM. Previously, he received and paid a loan of Kes 20,000 successfully.

loans.use: to buy a mill for grinding maize

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en:
Veronica is a 32-year-old married woman. She has one child. She describes herself to be a determined woman. She operates a grocery store  where she sells vegetables and fruit. She has been involved in this business for four years. Her business is located at  a potential business area. She describes her biggest business challenge to be inadequate funds for business expansion. 

Veronica will use the Kes 20,000 loan to buy vegetables and fruit to sell. Her business goal is to educate her child  within five years. This is her first loan with SMEP DTM.

loans.use: to buy fruit and vegetables

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en:
Rehema is a 38-year-old married woman. She has three children. She describes herself to be a sociable and talkative woman. She operates a grocery store  where she sells vegetables and fruit. She has been involved in this business for three years. Her business is located near an urban potential business area and her primary customers are local residents. 

Rehema describes her biggest business challenge to be insufficient funds for improving the business. She will use the Kes 20,000 loan to buy vegetables and fruit. Her business goal is to expand her business within five years. This is her second loan after taking a loan of Kes 15,000 which she managed to repay.

loans.use: to buy vegetables and fruit

loans.name: Vabah

texts.en:
Vabah lives in Montserrado county, in the area of Sinkor, one of the areas that is almost like the center of Monrovia. She is 38 years old, single, with three children between 5 and 19, that are attending school and live at home. Vabah is a ten-grade, 10th student. 

She has been operating a table in the local market for the past years where she sells rice, pepper, onion, red oil, salt, bitter-ball, and vita. The profits from her business are used on food and school fees. She started this business with money from her boyfriend. She spends eight hours on her business, and enjoys the buying from her customers. She uses a taxi to get her goods to her table from the wholesale market. 

Vabah is requesting a loan to purchase more rice, pepper, onion, red oil, salt, bitter-ball, and vita for her business. Her plan is to own a house for her family.

loans.use: to purchase more rice, pepper, onion, red oil, salt, bitter-ball, and vita for her business.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize and sorghum.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer to plant sorghum and maize

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer to plant sorghum and maize

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize and sorghum.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize and sorghum

loans.name: Geraida

texts.en: Gerailda is widowed with four children. None of her children go to school. She takes care of additional family members (grandchildren whom she pays school fees for). She has a business selling cereals and has been in this business for ten years. She generates additional income through selling piped water and airtime. She works from her home and sells at wholesale only. She has applied for a loan in Uganda shillings from MCDT-SACCO to buy more bags of rice.  Her major business challenges include seasonality and competition. She aspires to start to import rice herself from Kigumba and also to build rental houses. She resides in her own house and her family has access to electricity but not to piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family.

loans.use: to buy more bags of rice.

loans.name: Joan

texts.en:
Joan lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is single with two children and one of them attends school. She does not look after any other family members.

Joan has been operating a salon for six years, working six days a week. She does not have any other source of income.

Joan has requested a loan of UGX 300,000 from MCDT-SACCO to enable her to stock more hair oils, artificial hair, and rollers, and to replace old towels. Her challenges include seasonality, transport, and the unstable electricity supply. Joan's dream is to own a big beauty and recreation center and to train one of her children to follow suit.  She joined MCDT because of the low interest charged on loans. Joan lives in a house that she does not rent, with access to electricity and no piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include rent for her business premises and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more hair oils, artificial hair, and rollers, and to replace old towels.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is widowed with four children. All her children go to school. She has a business of selling tomatoes, onions and red pepper. She has been in this business for ten years, selling to all categories of people at retail.  

Rose has applied for a loan of 300,000 Uganda shillings from MCDT-SACCO to buy more boxes of tomatoes, onions and red pepper.  She works six days at the market out of every week. Her major business challenges include seasonality, thieves and perishability.  

Rose aspires to become a wholesaler and also to start growing those vegetables herself.

loans.use: to buy more tomatoes, onions and red pepper.

loans.name: Mastula

texts.en: Mastula is married with five children and only one of her children goes to school. She also takes care of additional family members (mother). She has a retail shop business and has been in this business for nine years. She has applied for a loan of 300 000 Uganda shillings from MCDT-SACCO to buy more bags of sugar, cartons of salt, and boxes of soap. She generates additional income through poultry farming. She works six days a week and sells on a retail basis. Her major business challenges include transportation and thieves. She is aspiring to own a fully stocked retail shop and to build her own house.  She resides in a rented house and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees, rent and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more sugar, salt and soap

loans.name: Florence

texts.en: Florence is a single mother of five children and two of her children go to school. She doesn’t take care of additional family members. She has had a food stall business for 10 years and has applied for a loan of 300,000 Uganda shillings from MCDT-SACCO to buy more boxes of tomatoes, onions, clusters of bananas and eggplants.  She doesn’t have any other income-generating activity. She works from her home seven days out of every week and sells on a retail basis only. Her major business challenges include thieves and defaulters. She is aspiring to become a wholesaler, to see her business grow big and to build her own house. She resides in a rented house and the family has access to electricity but not to piped water. Her monthly expenses includes school fees and rent.

loans.use: To buy more tomatoes, onions, bananas and eggplants

loans.name: Samoya Bidii Group

texts.en:
Jentrix’s group has 10 farmers and is located in Bungoma South District. Jentrix is pictured on the right of Samoya Bidii Group with her hand raised. Jentrix is pictured among the two men and eight women of her group. She will receive a loan capable of planting half an acre with sorghum and maize. Jentrix first enrolled with One Acre Fund during the 2011 long rains and is now preparing to be a One Acre Fund farmer during the 2013 long rains season. Jentrix joined One Acre Fund to gain access to hybrid seed and fertilizer as well as to improve her farming techniques with the One Acre Fund method.

Before joining One Acre Fund, Jentrix was only able to harvest four bags of maize per half acre, but after joining One Acre Fund during the long rains of 2012, she was able to harvest 14 bags per half acre! She plans to use future profits from the harvest to send her children to school and invest in livestock (buying a cow and poultry farming). During the 2013 long rains season, each group member will receive receive an acre of agricultural supplies on credit. Jentrix’s group will receive 4.5 acres worth of supplies on credit.

Catherine, a member of Samoya Bidii Group, is pictured above. However, her husband has already appeared on Kiva and she shares her OAF membership with him. In order to prevent the double funding of a farmer, she is pictured as a member of the group, but will not receive funding from this loan.

loans.use: to buy hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize, millet, and sorghum.

loans.name: Munyali A Group

texts.en:
Stella is a member of Munyali A Group in Bungoma South District. She is pictured with 10 One Acre Fund farmers, 4 women and 6 men. Stella is standing on the right with her hand raised. She is receiving an input loan for ½ acre of maize and sorghum cultivation. Stella is a new One Acre Fund farmer and is excited for the 2013 Long Rains season. She joined One Acre Fund in order to gain access to hybrid seeds and fertilizer as well as to grow enough food for the family.

Stella described her harvest last year as poor. She hopes that as a One Acre Fund farmer she is able to join the ranks of One Acre Fund farmers that have doubled their harvest in their first year of the program. She hopes that her profits from the 2013 Long Rains season can be used to send her children to school and invest in livestock (buy a cow). For the 2013 Long Rains season, Stella’s group members will take input loans of ½ acre each. In total, this group will receive input loans for use on 5 acres of land.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seeds and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize and sorghum.

loans.name: Subila Group

texts.en:
Catherine’s group has 10 farmers and is located in Bungoma South District. Catherine is pictured on the right of Subila Group with her hand raised. Catherine is pictured amongst the 3 men and 7 women of her group. She will receive input loans capable of planting ½ an acre with sorghum and maize. Catherine joined One Acre Fund during the Long Rains 2011, and is now enrolling in the Long Rains 2013 season. Catherine joined One Acre Fund so that she could rest assured of reliable input delivery and grow enough food for the family.

Catherine reports that before One Acre Fund, she was able to grow about 2 bags of maize per ½ acre, but with her One Acre Fund input loan during Long Rains 2012, she harvested 8 bags per 1/2 acre! She hopes that her profits from the 2013 Long Rains season can be used to start a poultry farm and save for the future. For the 2013 Long Rains season, Catherine’s group members will take input loans of ½ acre each. In total, this group will receive input loans for use on 5 acres of land.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seeds and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize and sorghum.

loans.name: Siritanyi C Group

texts.en:
Siritanyi C is a group of 10 farmers in Bungoma South District represented by Miriam. The group has 6 women and 4 men. Miriam is on the right of the photo with her hand raised. Farming inputs will be delivered to her on credit consisting of the necessary materials to plant ½ acre of maize and sorghum. The 2013 Long Rains season will be Miriam’s first season with One Acre Fund. She joined this year in order to gain access to hybrid seeds and fertilizers and use increased profits to send her children to school.

Miriam managed to harvest 5 bags of maize on 1 acre of land last year. As a One Acre Fund farmer, she hopes to harvest even more! She plans on using future profits from the harvest to send her children to school and to repair her home. During the 2013 Long Rains season, each group member will receive ½ an acre of agricultural inputs on credit. Miriam’s group will receive 5 acres worth of inputs on credit.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seeds and fertilizers for the cultivation of maize and sorghum

loans.name: Nally

texts.en: Nally is 43 years old and lives in Montserrado County, in the capital city of Liberia; it is well known as the commercial city  of Liberia. She is married and has two children, ages 11 and 15, and both of them are presently attending school. For the past five years Nally has been selling rice by the cup on a table in the local market. Her major problem is that the price of  rice is very high. She is requesting a loan to purchase more rice by the bag for her business. She plans to live a better life and get a house for her children.

loans.use: to purchase more rice by the bag for her business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy fabric for making clothes to sell

loans.name: Racheal

texts.en: Rachael lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is married with five children, four of whom are in school. She sells green bananas at the market on both a retail only and wholesale basis. She has no additional family members. Rachael has been in business for the last six years. She works seven days a week. Her major challenges are defaulters, transportation, and seasonality. She has requested a loan of 800,000 Ugandan shillings from MCDT SACCO to buy more bunches of bananas. She hopes to start selling on a wholesale only basis and wants to own a delivery van to ease her transportation. She lives in her own house and the family has no access to piped water and electricity. Her major monthly expenses include school fees.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of  bananas

loans.name: Simon

texts.en:
Simon is a 31-year-old married man. He has two children. He describes himself to be a quiet man. He operates a retail business where he sells mirrors and calendars. He has been involved in this business for five years. His business is located along a busy street opposite a potential shopping mall and his primary customers are businesspeople and the general public. He describes his biggest business challenge to be insufficient funds for improving the business. 

Simon will use the Kes 15,000 loan to buy calendars and mirrors to sell. His business goal is to expand his business within fivd years. This is his first loan with SMEP DTM. In addition, Simon does farming which increases his business income.

loans.use: to buy more calendars and mirrors to sell

loans.name: Clement

texts.en:
Clement is a 42-year-old man. He describes himself to be ambitious and an optimistic man. He operates a butcher shop  where he sells meat. He has been involved in this business for 14 years. His primary customers are local butcheries, restaurants and farmers. He describes his biggest business challenge to be inadequate meat for selling. 

Clement will use the Kes 20,000 loan to buy goats to slaughter for meat. His business goal is to be a large-scale distributor of meat within five years. This is his first loan with SMEP DTM.

loans.use: to buy more goats to slaughter for meat

loans.name: Teddy

texts.en:
Teddy  is married with eight children, and five of her children go to school. She doesn’t take care of additional family members. She has business of poultry farming and has been in this   business for eight years, selling to all categories of people but wholesale only, six days a week.  She has applied for a loan of Uganda shillings from MCDT SACCO to buy more  bags of chicken feed.

 She generates additional income from selling motor vehicle scrap. She works at the market .Her major business challenges include thieves and seasonality. She is aspiring   of owning a delivery van to ease transportation and also buying a plot of land and building rental rooms. She resides in a rented house and the family has no access to electricity or piped water. Her monthly expenses include rent and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more bags of chicken feed.

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence is a 51-year-old married woman. She has nine children with ages ranging from 7 years to 30 years. She describes herself to be ambitious and an optimistic woman. She operates a grocery store and retail business where she sells vegetables, fruit and baskets. She has been involved in this business for 10 years. Her business is located at a rural area and her primary customers are the general public from the environs. 

Florence describes her biggest business challenge to be insufficient funds for improving the business. She will use the Kes 10,000 loan to buy cabbages and tomatoes for resale. Her business goal is to expand her business within five years. This is her first loan with SMEP DTM.

loans.use: to buy cabbages and tomatoes to sell in her grocery store business

loans.name: Yah

texts.en:
Yah lives in Montserrado County, the capital city of Liberia, well-known as a commercial centre. A 45-year-old married mother of four children between 20 and 29 years of age, two of whom live at home, for the past four years Yah has been selling charcoal in the local market. Having learned this method of selling from her mother, she started the business with a little money from her husband.

Yah is requesting this loan to purchase more charcoal for her business, and plans to educate all of her children and eventually own a house.

loans.use: to purchase more charcoal for her business.

loans.name: Etendard 1, 2, 3 & 4 Group

texts.fr:
Milose est la coordonatrice de son groupe ETENDARD DE OUANAMINTHE Milose habite dans la ville de OUANAMINTHE d’Haiti où de l’éléctricité est rare et de l’eau est très limitée. Milose a dirigé son business pendant les 7 dernières années.

Avant de commencer ce commerce, Elle etait a l’ecole. Elle voudrait utiliser cet emprunt pour investir dans l’achat du produits alimentaires. Milose espère que cet emprunt l’aidera à agrandir son business. Les autres membres Etendard ont besoin d’un emprunt pour tels commerces comme vendre du charbon, du riz et des vetements uses. Milose dit que son défi principal est manque d’acheteur constant dit que ses buts principaux sont l’augmantation du bussiness.
texts.en:
Milose is the coordinator of her group "ETENDARD DE OUANAMINTHE".  She lives in Haiti, in the city of OUANAMINTHE, where electricity is scarce and the water supply very limited.  She has been managing her own business for the past seven years. Before getting involved in this commercial activity, she was in school. 

Milose would like to use her loan to invest in the purchase of food products.  She hopes that this loan will help her to expand her business.

The other members of the ETENDARD group need a loan to finance retail activities such as the sale of charcoal, rice, and used clothes.

Milose says that her main challenge is a constant lack of buyers.  Her main goal is to increase her business.

loans.use: to buy food products.

loans.name: Andrew

texts.en:
Andrew is a 35-year-old, married man. He has two children, six years and ten years old. He describes himself to be a social and talkative man. 

Andrew operates a retail shop where he sells electronics, such as phone accessories, spare parts, cell phone chargers, and cell phones. He has been involved in this business for six years. His business is located in an urban area and his primary customers are local residents. He describes his biggest business challenge to be insufficient funds for improving the business. 

Andrew will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy mobile phone accessories. His business goal is to expand his business within five years. He hopes that, in the future, he will educate his children. This is Andrew's first loan with SMEP Deposit Taking Microfinance Limited (SMEP DTM). In addition, Andrew does farming, which increases his business income.

loans.use: to buy mobile phone accessories for his shop.

loans.name: Cerapio

texts.en:
Cerapio is a master weaver from Peru who specializes in the Ayacucho style of tapestries. He would like to invest in the purchase of wool yarn and cotton thread to increase production.

Cerapio has been selling through NOVICA since 2000. This is his story:

"I was forced to leave my home in Ayacucho during the 1980s. Terrorists were bleeding my people to death and there seemed little hope. I inherited my passion for weaving from my parents and grandparents. But the quality of my work is the result of my long experience, and the product of my careful observation over the years. I draw inspiration from our ancient Peruvian cultures, Andean village life, and our snow-capped mountains.'

"Thanks to your support, I've grown as an artist, not only through sales, but also by developing many more designs. I thank you for your support with this microcredit."

Use the link below to view Cerapio's wool rugs and tapestries on the NOVICA site:
http://www.novica.com/kiva/194

loans.use: to invest in the purchase of wool yarn and cotton thread to increase production

loans.name: Jose Eduardo

texts.es:
José, se dedica a la crianza de cerdos, tiene 47 años de edad, está casado, su esposa y sus hijos de 18 y 22 años viven con él, su negocio es la crianza de cerdos y los comercializa, aprendió joven en su familia a realizar esta actividad.
Solicita un préstamo para la compra de cerdos y concentrado para alimentarlos, esta compra ayudara a que José incremente la granja y tenga lo necesario para engordarlos, tendrá la oportunidad de generar más ingresos.
La aspiración de José es fortalecer el negocio, ofrecer una mejor calidad de vida a su familia a través de su negocio.
texts.en:
Jose makes a living raising pigs.  He is 47 years old and is married.  His wife and two children (aged 18 and 22 years old) live with him.  His business is raising and selling pigs.  He learned this trade from his family when he was young.

Jose is applying for a loan to buy pigs and food to feed them.  Buying this will help Jose to increase the farm and to have the necessary supplies to fatten the pigs, and so generate a higher income. 

Jose aspires to strengthen the business and provide a better quality of life to his family, through his business.

loans.use: to buy pigs and feed.

loans.name: Mercedes

texts.en:
Born as the daughter of undocumented immigrant parents and having grown up in East Los Angeles, Ms. Mercedes witnessed not just the changes and growing vibrancy of the community, but also the struggles of working families. She also witnessed the injustice and poverty in a neighborhood that consists predominately of Latinos.

After receiving a degree in Public Policy and Management from the University of Southern California and her J.D. from the University of California at Davis, Mercedes returned to her roots and opened her law office in September 2010. Her office is really a community project, offering low-cost legal services and know-your-rights information seminars. 

Mercedes envisioned her legal practice, located on busy Whittier Blvd., to be one to educate and empower the East Los Angeles community. In the last two years, Mercedes has helped hundreds of East Los Angeles residents to avoid deportation and separation from their families. She protected their rights in accordance with the law and helped others to confront domestic violence issues. 

Mercedes has also envisioned uplifting community residents by mentoring some to explore pursuing legal professions and becoming advocates for their own community. She works with local non-profit organizations like the East Los Angeles Women’s Center, Corazon del Pueblo, and neighboring schools and colleges by providing seminars and workshops.

Realizing that the demand for her services is much higher than she had envisioned, Mercedes will expand her practice with the $10,000 KIVA loan and continue to offer pro bono educational services. She will use this loan to purchase computers, laptops and projectors to be used by volunteers and law students, and also to hire a legal assistant.

loans.use: to purchase computers and to hire a new employee for her law office.

loans.name: Milly

texts.en:
Milly is married and has one child, who goes to school. She also takes care of additional family members (sister). Milly has operated a clinic for 5 years. She works from her home seven days every week on a retail basis only. Milly's major business challenges are defaulters, seasonality, thieves and the ever increasing prices of medicines in Uganda.

Milly has applied for a loan of 1,000,000 Uganda shillings from MCDT-SACCO to buy more boxes of drugs, syringes and syrups. She hopes to own a fully stocked clinic or drug shop and to upgrade her clinic to a hospital. Milly resides in a rented house and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees and rent.

loans.use: To buy more drugs, syringes and syrups

loans.name: Musu

texts.en: Musu, 45 years old, lives in Montserrado County in the capital city of Liberia, well known as a commercial city. She is married and has five children aged between 17 and 20 years old, all in school and living at home. For the past eight years, Musu has been selling charcoal in her community. She started this business with her father's help and learned this way of selling from him. Musu likes her business because she makes more profit. She is requesting a loan to buy more charcoal for her business. Musu's dream is to get  money to build a house.

loans.use: to buy more charcoal for her business,

loans.name: Diego

texts.en:
Diego is a wood-carver from Guatemala. Diego would like to stock up on raw materials for his hand-carved sculptures and masks and also buy an electric jigsaw. Diego has been selling through NOVICA since 2010. This is his story:

"I am a Maya woodcarver. At age 10, I left school to help my father work in the fields. Eventually, I began selling wooden masks, then learned to carve and paint them, while still helping my father. I am a devout Catholic, so I then began carving images of saints. Today, I have taught my art to six people, and I have been able to put my children, who are also wood carvers, through school.

"I'm very grateful to you because you're helping me a lot. Sometimes, I don't sell much, so this money helps me to continue working and producing. The micro-credit last year was a huge help, as you gave me a hand at a time when things were really tough for me. I want to buy an electric jigsaw, which will help me work faster and improve my quality because, at the moment, we do the cutting with a machete."

Use the link below to view Diego's wood sculptures and masks on the NOVICA site:
http://www.novica.com/kiva/7299

loans.use: to stock up on raw materials for his hand-carved sculptures and masks and also to buy an electric jigsaw.

loans.name: Rosa Antonia

texts.es:
Rosa, tiene 53 años de edad, está casada, tiene dos hijas que estudian en la universidad y dependen de ella económicamente, administra una pupuseria en la que trabaja de  Martes a Domingo, por las tardes, sus hijas le ayudan en el negocio, su experiencia es de cinco años.
Solicita un préstamo para la compra de mesas, una plancha para hacer pupusas nueva, gas, esto le ayudara a que incremente la posibilidad de generar más ingresos, aumentando su venta.  
Su objetivo es con el préstamo fortalecer más el negocio y ofrecer una mejor condición de vida con su trabajo.
texts.en:
Fifty-three year old Rosa is married.  She has two daughters, both of whom are studying at university and who depend on Rosa financially.  Rosa makes and sells stuffed tortillas.  She works in the afternoons from Tuesday through to Sunday and her daughters help with the business.  She has five years experience.

She is applying for a loan to buy tables, gas and a new grill for making the stuffed tortillas.  The loan will help Rosa possibly to increase her income, by increasing her sales.

Her aim is to use the loan to strengthen her business and, with her work, offer better living conditions.

loans.use: to buy tables, gas and a new grill for making stuffed tortillas.

loans.name: Josphine

texts.en: Josphine, 56 years old, is married and has 7 children whose ages range from 16 to 36 years old. She describes herself as a social woman. For the past 3 years, Josphine has operated a retail business weaving and selling baskets. Her business is located in an urban area and her primary customers are local residents. Josphine describes her biggest business challenge to be the shortage of weaving materials. She will use this KES 10,000 loan to buy weaving materials for making more baskets to sell. Josphine's business goal is to expand her business and employ many people within 5 years. She hopes that, in the future, she will have improved her business. This is Josphine's first loan with SMEP DTM. She also farms to increase her business income.

loans.use: to buy basket weaving materials for making more baskets to sell

loans.name: Victor

texts.en:
Victor is a Peruvian artisan who specializes in handcrafted silver jewelry. He would like to invest in the purchase of larger amounts of silver and natural gemstones.

Victor has been selling through NOVICA since 2010. This is his story:

"Jewelry is my life. It impassions me. Each design is like a child to me. My artistic formation began when I was 12, when my older sister married an experienced silversmith. I was an apprentice at his workshop, and then became a master silversmith, too. I love the thrill of working on new designs."

"Thanks to you and your collaboration in this microcredit, I'll be able to create more designs and thus increase my production, which is inspired by nature, as always!"

Use the link below to view Victor's silver jewelry on the NOVICA site:
http://www.novica.com/kiva/7269

loans.use: to invest in the purchase of larger amounts of silver and natural gemstones

loans.name: Francis

texts.en:
Francis is an artisan from Ghana who specializes in hand-carved wooden masks and sculptures as well as in leather items. He would like to invest in the purchase of more local woods, polish, sandpaper and glue.

Francis has been selling through NOVICA since 2003. This is his story:

"I come from a family of traditional wood carvers. While at school, funding was becoming difficult, so during weekends and vacations, I would visit my father's workshop and assist him by carving some products for sale. The realization eventually dawned on me to stay on, work on my own designs, and display my own woodcarvings. I opened a new workshop, which my sister and a cousin manage, and together we preserve the family legacy." 

"Thank you so much for taking part in this microcredit, because it will help me increase my stock. I pray that you keep on doing what you're doing to be able to support artisans like me."

Use the link below to view Francis's wood masks and leather desk sets on the NOVICA site:
http://www.novica.com/kiva/3835

loans.use: to invest in the purchase of more local woods, polish, sandpaper and glue

loans.name: Wilson

texts.en:
Wilson is an artisan in Ghana who specializes in carving traditional masks. He would like to invest in the purchase of more local wood and polish.

Wilson has been selling through NOVICA since 2004. This is his story:

"I became interested in Ghanaian African carvings when I was a child, so after middle school I learned the trade through a man named Mr. Akoffour. Now I have my own workshop and am training three people. I carve different types of masks and each of them has a meaning. My products are unique and my goal is to create more."

"I thank you all for contributing to this microcredit. It will help me keep in business doing what I love."

Use the link below to view Wilson's African masks on the NOVICA site:
http://www.novica.com/kiva/4507

loans.use: to invest in the purchase of more local wood and polish

loans.name: Abdeljabbar

texts.en:
AbdelJabbar is a 26-year-old single young man. He lives a simple life with his family in Jenin. He is employed and gets a low salary which is barely enough to cover his needs.

AbdelJabbar is requesting a loan from FATEN to cover the cost of purchasing a new refrigerator for his family to use at home. Taking this loan will offer AbdelJabbar and his family better living conditions. AbdelJabbar is photographed in the picture.

loans.use: To purchase a new refrigerator for home-use.

loans.name: Vangie

texts.en:
After a car accident, Vangie’s insurance company claimed her car was a complete loss and issued funds to replace it. Agreeing to repurchase her car and repair its front suspension per her husband’s suggestion, Vangie was informed her vehicle was up for auction and she would have to bid for it. 

Vangie returned with three vehicles from the auction, none of which were her original. She then hired a mechanic to repair them before selling them. The vehicles sold quicker than Vangie expected, so she then decided to continue purchasing vehicles from auctions, creating a new career for herself.

It’s been 15 years since Vangie’s first sale. She now carries 40 to 50 trucks, cars, SUVs, vans, blue title and salvaged-titled cars purchased from auctions at her buy-here-pay-here lot, A & V Auto Sales, located in her hometown of San Antonio.

Compared to the multiple car lots in San Antonio and its surrounding cities, Vangie says her car lot is different because, “We try to work with everybody, and if they have problems with their cars after the purchase, we’ll go the extra mile to fix it. If I have the parts, I’ll give them to you, just pay for the labor.”

Vangie has always been an entrepreneur. Her passion to sell began as a child selling various items at yard sales with her mom. As she grew older, Vangie made seasonal trips to Mexico to purchase wrought iron presents to sell in the U.S.A. and earn a small profit during the Christmas season.
